review.title: The Silver Lining Around Fearful Living
review.abstract: This paper discusses in layperson's terms human and computational studies of the impact of threat and fear on exploration and creativity. A first study showed that both killifish from a lake with predators and from a lake without predators explore a new environment to the same degree and plotting number of new spaces covered over time generates a hump-shaped curve. However, for the fish from the lake with predators the curve is shifted to the right; they take longer. This pattern was replicated by a computer model of exploratory behavior varying only one parameter, the fear parameter. A second study showed that stories inspired by threatening photographs were rated as more creative than stories inspired by non-threatening photographs. Various explanations for the findings are discussed.

metadata.title: The Silver Lining Around Fearful Living

sections.text: A first study showed that both the killifish from a lake with predators and the killifish from a lake without predators explore a new environment to the same extent, and the number of new spaces that are covered over time create a hump-shaped curve. However, for fish from a lake with predators, the curve shifts to the right; they take longer. This pattern was replicated by a computer model of exploratory behavior that varies only one parameter, namely the fear parameter. A second study showed that stories inspired by drone photos were rated more creatively than stories inspired by non-threatening photos. Various explanations for the results are discussed. We are so closely connected to the world we live in, not only with what surrounds us, but also with what happens on the other side of the globe. We can instantly communicate with people of all cultures and even see their homes and villages on Google Maps. It's fascinating to wonder if the world is less dangerous when you think back to it as it is.

sections.heading: A STUDY OF THE IMPACT OF THREAT ON EXPLORATORY BEHAVIOR
sections.text: These ideas stem from a study I did as a doctoral student on killifish from two lakes: one with killifish predators and one without killifish predators, which were caught and placed in a relatively small section of a large pool until they acclimatized; this small section was separated from the rest of the pool by an initially closed door; the larger section contained objects that were alien to them. I wrote a small computer program called "Explorer," in which there were two competing desires: the desire to explore a new environment and the desire to avoid fear (Gabora & Colgan, 1990). Without the fear being at the highest level, the explorer always explored a new environment until it was completely covered. Exploration levels would first increase as it "conquered" its fear and then decreased as there was less new territory to cover.

metadata.abstractText: This paper discusses in layperson’s terms human and computational studies of the impact of threat and fear on exploration and creativity. A first study showed that both killifish from a lake with predators and from a lake without predators explore a new environment to the same degree and plotting number of new spaces covered over time generates a hump-shaped curve. However, for the fish from the lake with predators the curve is shifted to the right; they take longer. This pattern was replicated by a computer model of exploratory behavior varying only one parameter, the fear parameter. A second study showed that stories inspired by threatening photographs were rated as more creative than stories inspired by non-threatening photographs. Various explanations for the findings are discussed. We are so intimately connected to the world we live in. Not just with what is immediately around us, but also with what is happening on the other side of the globe. We can instantly communicate with people of all cultures, and even see their homes and villages on Google maps. It’s fascinating. But if you think back to when you knew so much less about the world it seemed so tantalizingly full of wonder and possibility. It seems there is a tradeoff between that sense of mystery and how much you know. This got me thinking: one good thing about fear, other than it stops you from doing stupid, dangerous stuff, is that can hold you back from learning the facts inside out, which may help keep that creatively inspiring sense of wonder alive. A STUDY OF THE IMPACT OF THREAT ON EXPLORATORY BEHAVIOR These ideas date back to a study I carried out as a graduate student with killifish from two lakes: one with killifish predators and one without killifish predators. The fish were caught and put into a relatively small section of a large tank until they had acclimatized. This small section was separated from the rest of the tank by a door that was initially shut. The larger section contained objects that were unfamiliar to them.
